name: New Caster wants to know: Fireball vs. Scintillating Sphere
author: UrbanHermit

posts.author: UrbanHermit
posts.content:
Greetings, all. I have returned to this game after many years under the allure of the Enhanced Edition and decided to try a caster for the first time instead of my usual preference for melee characters. Going with a Sorceress, because... reasons!

Anyhoo, my lovely little budding human Sorc has been merrily working her way through chapter one of the OC, anxiously running circles around a mage-armor-buffed Daelan or Grimnaw to draw aggro to them (as I have read in many places is the thing to do) while praying for good rolls from her Wand of Sleep, plinking away at what she can with a crossbow and taking a shot with Burning Hands when it seems efficient to do so. Actually, she soloed the open streets in Beggar's Nest because the slow moving zombies are just such ripe (pun intended), and fun, targets for Burning Hands.

Now, we've got level III spells just around the corner and the seemingly obvious Fireball as a choice. But, in looking at the other "nuke" in the third level arsenal, I see that Scintillating Sphere is basically the same spell other than range and element. I know it might seem like a no-brainer that the greater range is better, but I've been playing around with Pretty Good Character Creator in the test area and happen to think the electric zap is cooler than the fire blast.

And we all know that looking cool is important.

Considering that just about EVERYthing rushes you to melee in this game, does the range really matter all that much? Is there ever a good reason for the preference of lightning over fire in the earlier levels? I do realize it's just a level 3 spell and other things will be more important a little further down the road. But I'm one of those people who enjoys the leveling process, trying to learn what I can, and having a little fun along the way.

tldr: Is there ever a reason to take Scintillating Sphere over Fireball?

posts.author: UrbanHermit
posts.content:
Only when I started casting Scintillating Sphere I realised I had to walk closer as a mage to cast it. Often the enemy would see me before I cast destroying the element of surprise / targeting.
Yeah, I realized that tonight. It's a notable difference in wide open spaces. Probably less so in dungeons and interiors where you have umpteen guards/goblins/whatever suddenly swarming the doorway you just opened.

As it happened, my Sorc leveled up on the 3rd kill upon entering the Docks District. So I did my usual pre-level-up-save and then made a couple runs with both of these spells, with Daelan in tow, against the Muggers and Thugs roaming the streets, as well as Androd's mansion for some close quarter action. I had him stand his ground while I did the casting from a distance thing and found out you do get fewer surprise attacks with the shorter range.

Having the henchman ball them up is mostly pointless because between cleave and attacks of opportunity, they can drop 3 enemies in the time it takes you to wind up one spell and your big AoE nuke of glory fizzles out on a single target.

I then tried a third option and swapped out Melf's for Flame Weapon and took the Dire Wolf summon for that first level 3 spell. Dismissed Daelan and did the run again with just the wolf, and I gotta say... I was pleasantly surprised. A level 6 Flame Weapon feels like it lasts a looong time and the wolf has knockdown to boot. At this point I think it's a better option than just having 4 AoE spells that might do good damage.

From what I've been reading this is not all that surprising nor disappointing. She's still basically a humble party buffer whose crossbow bolts of lightning and frostbite do more damage than a few spells per day. And Burning Hands is still useful at this level, methinks.

Still not decided on the two spells in question, nor have I dismissed them altogether, either. Just putting them on hold for now, so the feedback is still muchly appreciated.

tldr: Dire Wolf + Flame Weapon beats Fireball/Shockball... for now.

posts.author: Valerfor

@ UrbanHermit, when you become more experienced with your Sorceress you will see that almost all of the direct damage spells in the game are sub-par, to say the least. posts.author: Ten Pura
posts.content:
UrbanHermit,
As a frequent wizard player, I don't usually find myself taking many damage dealing spells until I get 4th level spells. The buffs are just too good, especially when combined with a decent henchman and a summon.

To illustrate at level 8 (for sorcerer, 7 for wizard), drop an extended Flame Weapon, regular Bull's, and regular Mage Armor on a summoned dire wolf. Watch the magic happen.

Also, both Scintillating Sphere and Fireball top out at caster level 10, making other spells much more useful at 11+.
My favorite level 3 buffs:
Greater Magic Weapon
Haste
Keen Edge

Utility:
Find Traps
Summon Monster III

My favorite level 3 offensive spells:
Flame Arrow
Stinking Cloud
Negative Energy Burst
Slow

In particular, Flame Arrow and Negative Energy Burst are both lack-luster at low levels, but really start to become great at caster level 20+. In contrast, Stinking Cloud and Slow are always nice.

To further expand on my fondness for Stinking Cloud, it's great as an area denial effect. Unless the targets are poison immune (monks, druids, or gear), it's AoE with a round/level duration. Even against high saves, everyone rolls a 1 eventually. Its daze shuts down most offensive actions and renders characters without uncanny dodge flat-footed. Sit back, let your elemental summon melee in the cloud, while you shoot them with a crossbow, cast other spells, loot, or get a drink all while standing off to the side in safety. With the creatures in the cloud rolling to save every round, combined with the duration, Stinking Cloud clearly out performs most other level 3 spells. It may not be as flashy, or do any damage, but it will cause the demise of your opponents.

A final thought, if you play wizard, this is another reason to take a level of rogue early. Those crossbow shots on dazed opponents will all be sneak attacks.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
IMO there is a tangible shift in power for sorcerers when they reach level 8 - 10.
Before that you rely on summons/ familiars/ henchmen as buffed frontliners.
Once you get Stoneskin and Improved invisibility in addition to your lower level buffs, your character can take more punishment, becomes more independent and can start casting attack spells more regularly. Fireball will still be effective at those levels, both in level 3 and 4 slots.  But once you get Firebrand it becomes your new Big Stick.

posts.author: UrbanHermit
posts.content:
IMO there is a tangible shift in power for sorcerers when they reach level 8 - 10.
Before that you rely on summons/ familiars/ henchmen as buffed frontliners.
Some interesting advice I came across from another forum from many years ago was this:

Levels 1-3, hide behind the tank.
Levels 4-6, you still hide behind the tank, but now you can cast Identify a lot.
Levels 7-low teens, keep the tank around but now you can deal some damage.
Levels low teens and up, ditch the tank. You ARE the tank.

I re-rolled that last level-up and went back and fought Brother Toras again with Linu, the Cleric hench, in tow. I had the party "stand their ground" and pulled most of his minions back to us before running in for him, this time.

Linu and her bear worked his few remaining minions, my sorc and her wolf handled bro Toras. Lesser Spell Mantle scroll for her (along with a ring of elemental resistance), Lesser Spell Breach scroll for him. X-bow+flame bolts, Wolf+Flame Weapon, Melf's Acid Arrow and Magic Missiles and he actually went down fairly quick.

That's another thing, I'm using scrolls a lot more with this character. Others I've played have always ended up with a huge collection of unused scrolls in their packs because I kept holding onto to them for "that really important fight that's surely to come soon."

Okay, out of respect and admiration for the "elite" character builders here, I guess it's time for me to confess... I'm not playing a pure Sorcerer. I gave her 3 levels of Bard. It's a theme build. You know... the singing sorceress thing. Yes, I'm aware that there are no real synergies with Sorcerer/Bard other than sharing Charisma. But, it is the OC and I knew this was basically going to be a henchman/summons support play-through, ending at around level 17, and decided to have a little RP fun with it.

I used the Bard levels for skill dumps. 10 points Tumble, 5 points UMD at level 10. With 20 CHA that makes 10 UMD which allowed her to buy monk gear from the priest at Tyr's Temple in chapter 2. Dark Moon Robes for the perma-haste +4 AC, and Sun Soul Boots for the +2 Dodge AC. Add +1 from 12 DEX and +2 from Tumble and she's got 19 AC unbuffed in cloth. Mage Armor + Shield + a potion of Barkskin and she's at 28 AC.

Level 3 Bard Song gives +1 Attack and +2 Damage, essentially making it a temporary universal combo of Weapon Focus + Weapon Specialization for the henches and summons, as well as her own X-bow shots. Extra Music taken at Bard 1 lets her sing 7 times per day.

At level 12, now, she's got Extend Spell, Greater Spell Penetration and Spell Focus: Evocation (in anticipation of Firebrand).

Other than delaying her Sorcerer levels, it seems to be working pretty good, so far. But it's the Sorcerer class that has me the most interested, and hence, my inquiry here. I have every intention of playing a pure Sorcerer for a second run through SoU/HotU after this friendly little romp through the OC. Which, I imagine, is where the real Sorcerer training will take place. Following that I'd finally like to get around to taking on The Aielund Saga with an Exalted Sorceress, or similar build.

I humbly thank those who have thus far replied and appreciate your kind indulgence of my ramblings.

They likely forget it/it's a bug, that's not uncommon at all to happen in games with such broad scope when the developer teams try to get them ready for release in a relatively short amount of time. Many such "mistakes" can be found in the game & other games too. For example, if you look at Baldur's Gate files for Drizzt in the program you will see that in the initial version (not the EE) he had his weapons equipped on his head slot & his game class was "Innocent!" Or that for Neverwinter Nights, Giants & the rest of the big guys might wield two-handed swords but they actually inflict damage equal to the one-handed version of it, some of them have actually equipped shields that don't show properly in their game models, etc.

Back then (late 90's / mid-2000s) the developer teams were counted in a dozen people or two at most, nowadays it is common for developer teams to consist of 200+ members & they still release games with several bugs that they later "fix" through live updates...

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Icewind Dale was always second-fiddle to Baldur's Gate Saga. You wonder from dungeon to dungeon & kill things, buy more stuff then kill bigger things & somewhere in there is a story that may or may not get to you. There is no interaction between the NPCs neither the brilliant magic system of its big brother. That being said, IWD 1 is superior to IWD 2 & it has some strengths versus BG, namely the lovely music & art-style. There is also more combat involved in general.



Planescape Torment goes the other way around. It is considered by some to be even greater than BG (it is not) because the story is superb (nameless one) the interactions between the NPCs are the best but there is one big caveat. There is almost next to no combat. It also features some very "cinematic" high-level spells, those must have been the best the world had seen by that time, truly next level in production value.



And then, there is Temple of Elemental Evil, not an Infinity Engine game but a good D&D 3.0 RPG with similar UI to Baldur's Gate but with two important differences. One is that the game is turn-based & not real-time with pause (better for some people, but I prefer real-time action)  & the other is that the game is taking place mostly in a big dungeon crawl, so its scope is limited in comparison. Still a good game though & one of the last of that era.



In my opinion, though, Baldur's Gate Saga trumps them all, with ease. It doesn't get more epic than that, it simply doesn't!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I can't remember for the life of me what I included in Triology, but I do recall I got all my info from Spellhold Studios - which I assume is still going - if that's any use?

Installing Triology is by no means mandatory, but its main benefit is that those party members you'll likely have travelled with during BG1 who are also available in BG2 (by no means all of them) will retain the levels and skills you've given them during the first campaign (weapon proficiencies, spells, etc), while without Trilogy they will have their default skillset for BG2.

You will be given romance options in BG2 (it doesn't feature in BG1), regardless of whether you install Trilogy or not, one of which in particular brings plenty of xp as it progresses through its long-term unfolding. You are, of course, free to decline them (or indeed have your prospective "partner" chuck you if you give the "wrong" responses).

There are also many side-quests in BG2 given to you by NPCs (some of which require said NPC to travel with you, but most do not), together with your own "stronghold" quest (which depends on what sort of character you're playing - warrior, mage, thief, etc). These all add colour, as well as xp and gear, but the main point of them is to get you to the level you will need to be to have any chance of success by the time you reach the finale. This is as true for BG1 as it is for BG2. Throne of Bhaal is much more linear (and all the poorer for it). In essence, explore the world of Baldur's Gate as much as you can - it's a marathon, not a sprint!

Hope this helps a bit.

Cheers

EDIT: I would still install Dark Side of the Sword Coast. Albeit it's an "unofficial" BG1 module, it's perfectly compatible with the main game and requires no additional installations. It brings with it more and better gear and foes, together with an assortment of additional companions. These will benefit you throughout, regardless of whether you decide to complete the Dark Side quest line or not.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
If you have bought the original saga instead of the GOG release (Enhanced Edition) then there are three primary ways to play the game:

a) Play it like Stag does, with the Trilogy mod, that may take hundreds of other mods & stack them to the base game & offers a sort of pseudo-continuity between BG I & II.

b) Play it with the Easy TuTu setup which is a lot "lighter" than "Trilogy" & offers a more plain-jane experience but closer to authentic. This is what I used to play after having a few of the Original Saga experiences. Here's the link to that => https://usoutpost31.com/easytutu/

c) Play it with just the Original Game, it's Expansion & the Baldurdash fixes. Unfortunately, I won't be able to show you that way because the domain/site has expired after twenty years or so & it's fixes are instead incorporated to the Gibberlings3 fixpack (Baldur's Gate II Fixpack) that despite the name works perfectly well for BG1 as well.  Here's the link to the fixpack => https://gibberlings3.github.io/Document ... xpack.html

Now, here is where these three ways differentiate from each-other: The Original Saga + Baldurdash fixpack is all using the BG1 engine to run everything. There is none of the BG2 spells or enhancements/nerfs to the game. It is the "Vanilla" thing. That means between others, that arrows, for example, are "killers" & that there are no dual-wielding options or stoneskin spell yet, neither are available spell-triggers & such. The weapons are all separated in very broad categories (swords long & short for example, instead of katanas, longswords, short-swords, greatswords, etc.) & there is a distinct "Stoney" UI that through it you play the game.

Vanilla Game Inventory UI
https://simg.chomikuj.pl/093f308e1ff8cd ... embers.png

The Easy Tutu setup is using the BG II engine (& all of its enchantments) to play both games meaning the game (BG1), overall, it's easier than intended because you can now have half-orc fighters that start with 19Str/19Con, you have dual-wielding & you have Stoneskin for your mages. To counter that up, the game uses a few more spawns were it should & it works quite well, especially if you have never seen the Original. Contrastingly, arrows are a lot weaker now, walking speed has been increased & most importantly AD&D's "Kits" for each class have entered the game. You'll no longer have a plain fighter but a lot of specializations to choose from, including the mighty Berserker. Paladins now have the Cavalier option & Mages can now choose the Sorceress! The game is still awesome & you'll quickly forget the differences once start playing, it's the gameplay that will keep you up the nights, not the graphics (as is the case with Neverwinter Nights).

Easy TuTu Inventory UI



The Trilogy setup is much like Easy TuTu but it also has the option for hundreds of mods that it handily manages for you (This is referring as "The Big World setup") & it offers its own take on the transition between BGI & II. The UI & everything is completely BG II on this.

Baldur's Gate Trilogy Inventory UI
https://media.moddb.com/images/members/ ... entory.jpg


And just for contrast, the Enhance dEdition's Invenroty UI
https://us.v-cdn.net/5019558/uploads/Fi ... be4506.jpg


About the Dark Side mod, I would personally avoid it for my first playthrough with the game. To put it simply it completely changes the gameplay balance of the game introducing high-magic variables in every category. NPCs, Items, Spells, Levels, Enemies, etc. but I would instead suggest you to try it after you have completed the Original game at least once.

Now, my apologies for this wall-o-text but as a final comment, I would like to ask you (Stag or anyone else that knows BG II well enough). Doesn't the game music before you enter Yaga-Shura's temple reminds you of Basilis Poledouris CONAN?

Back when Black Isle started the game they have very limited funds so...It is rumored that almost all the women portraits in the game are, in fact, the same person, just with minor alterations. If you look more closely you'll see that  => http://mikesrpgcenter.com/bgate/npcs.html

Baldur's Gate & Icewind Dale & Planescape Torment, all use AD&D 2nd Edition Rules.
Thac0 stands for (To Hit AC zero) and it's a simple subtraction of your roll vs the AC (Armor Class) of the target.
For example, say your fighter has Thac0 15 & you roll 13 on d20 & the Ogre has an AC of 5.
Thac0 15 - 13 = 2 (You could hit an AC of 2 or higher), the Ogre has an AC of 5, so your fighter easily scores a hit against it.

In general: Thac0 & Saving throws = The lower the better.

The game manual will explain the rest, it's very easy to read => https://www.oldgames.sk/en/game/baldurs ... load/6079/
For anything else, you might have questions for, just ask ;)
